Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that a whistleblower accusing the Philippine VP of fraud surfaced in December 2020, when there is no evidence or reliable news reports to support this.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no reliable evidence or news reports to back up the existence of a whistleblower accusing the Philippine VP of fraud in late 2020.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the video posted on YouTube is a valid and credible source of information, without providing any additional supporting evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation is that the video in question is taken from a previous video streamed in May 2016, suggesting that the claims made in the video are not new or recent.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Robredo was proclaimed vice president by Congress in 2016, as evidenced by a YouTube video from May 2016.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting misleading information and relying on a video that is not recent or related to the alleged whistleblower accusation in December 2020.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
